**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: Yannas is not a modification case and does not apply a "substantial and material change" standard. It is a removal case decided in the context of an initial divorce/custody judgment, articulating the "real advantage" test and best‑interests analysis under G.L. c. 208, § 30. While it is relevant to relocation/removal standards, it does not stand for the proposition that particular post‑judgment facts constitute a substantial and material change warranting modification under Yannas, Mason, and Schuler.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30… provides that… [a child] shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… In this process, the first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’”

**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: These facts constitute a substantial and material change supporting modification under the standards elaborated in **Yannas v. **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman deals with the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth when parents share joint legal and physical custody, specifically interpreting “cause shown” under G.L. c. 208, § 30 as a best-interests test and contrasting that with the Yannas standard applied in sole-physical-custody cases. It does not articulate or apply a “substantial and material change” standard for modification in the Schuler sense, nor does it say that a given set of facts constitutes such a change. Thus, citing Mason as authority that particular facts amount to a substantial and material change under Yannas/Mason/Schuler misstates its holding and use.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:

‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]…’

…We turn to the propriety of the judge’s order denying permission for the mother to remove the children. The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move.”

Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: Schuler addresses the general standard for modification of alimony/support—requiring a material change in circumstances—but it holds that the husband did NOT demonstrate a sufficient change and affirms denial of modification. It does not treat the identified facts as constituting a substantial and material change; instead, it treats them as insufficient when balanced against his earning capacity and assets. Thus, while it states the ‘material change’ standard, it does not support the specific proposition that these types of facts constitute a substantial and material change warranting modification under that standard.
**Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment… In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances… A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered… However, while a substantial decrease in income or financial status may warrant a modification, such a decrease does not alone compel a modification.”

**Smith v. **Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)*.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that modification requires both (1) a material change in circumstances, and (2) that the modification serve the child’s best interests.

**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that modification requires both (1) a material change in circumstances, and (2) that the modification serve the child’s best interests.

App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the statutory standard for modification of custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28: it requires both (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties and (2) that the judgment of modification be necessary in the best interests of the children. The court then applies that dual requirement, holding there was no qualifying material change to justify modifying custody, thereby affirming that both prongs are needed for modification.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

**Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.support_reasoning: Hale v. Hale is a removal-of-children case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a modification-of-custody or modification-of-judgment case. **Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ in the controlling statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, set forth in the margin, have been interpreted to permit removal if in the best interests of the child. Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). However, the criteria for determining such best interests have, as yet, not been established, and decisions of the trial court as to whether removal should be allowed have been upheld without much discussion.”

**Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion is centrally about the best-interests standard in custody disputes and emphasizes that domestic violence and its effects on the child must be explicitly considered. It does reference some factors like the child’s relationship with each parent, school performance, prior caregiving, and the child’s stated preference, but it does not articulate a general test specifying that age, needs, emotional ties, living arrangements, and stability must be considered. Its holding is focused on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence, not on laying out the multi-factor best-interests framework described in the proposition.
**Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’… Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

**Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard, as reaffirmed in **Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996)** and **Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. **Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly reaffirms that the governing principle in custody cases is the welfare or best interests of the child and that all relevant factors must be weighed, but it does not enumerate the specific factors listed in the proposition (age, needs, emotional ties, living arrangements, stability). It mentions only relative parental environments and the length and effect of the child’s current placement, so it supports the general best-interests standard, not the more detailed, factor-specific formulation claimed.
**Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment… and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”

**Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677.relevant_excerpt: “Consistent with the views of other jurisdictions, we conclude that a judge is not foreclosed by G.
